That's a great, that's a great point.
And that is, yeah, it's, that's the thing is it's a good thing that God has given us.
And then our temptation is to make it about us versus about him.
And that's true for, again, that's, that sounds so churchy.
Like, oh, everybody says that.
No, I mean, I say it because it's true.
No matter what our talents and gifts are, whether it's, you know, it's something, something
more simple, something more common, something more hidden, something more public, something
more dramatic, like whatever it is, if it's, if your abilities are incredibly gifted at
music or incredibly gifted at technology, like none of those, those are all still about
him.
Right.
For the Christian, our identity is still in him.
It doesn't, it's not just the preacher who has this problem, it's everybody.
But preachers get to fall in really dynamic ways.
Right.
And as part of it, every, a lot of Christians fall in their faith at different times, but
when, when big lead pastors, especially big tens of thousands mega church member pastors
do it, well, it makes news.
I mean, that's like it's splash.
And so, so just, just being able to say, how do I, what are the boundaries I put in my
life?
I mean, we look at a guy like Billy Graham, who, man, I think, I think if there was scandal,
it would have come out by now.
Because everybody wanted there to be a scandal about him.
And he didn't.
And I think it's because he was humble enough and he drew healthy boundaries in his life
around his marriage and his family.
And I mean, there were stories about, you know, he had to send people into hotel rooms
ahead of him because people would find out where he was going to be.
And they would station a photographer and a naked woman in the room and try to catch
him in a photo.
And I don't know if that's true, if that's just legend, but I remember reading, hearing
about that kind of stuff and thinking, man, that's how hard people wanted this guy to
fall.
And he didn't.
And so to examine his life and try to figure out, okay, how did he, I mean, he was at the
level of power and authority and influence in the world that people were probably trying
to get into fall left and right to use, to abuse his influence, abuse his power.
And it doesn't seem like he did, which is, you know, that is a miracle, not because of
Billy Graham, because he's human.
Right.
Exactly.
And the other thing, man, is to have that type of success, attention and notoriety and
not fall.
I respect, I respect any president or governor or leader who doesn't fall because I know
they have the opportunity to.
Yeah.
So it's a big deal.
And we don't, of course, we don't hear about the thousands of pastors who faithfully pastor
their whole lives and never stumble in any, you know, career ending or ministry ending
way.
Yeah.
And they don't stumble.
Everyone does.
Right.
But it's not like, yeah, to where it's like they completely lose their witness.
Yeah.
And so another thing that I've heard you say, Chris, is when you're talking about kind of
younger, the younger generation, when they, because they've seen a lot of pastors fall,
when they see a young leader, they tend to think, oh, well, he just hasn't fallen yet.
Mm hmm.
Does how, how does that kind of play into because I'm sure there are people who are
of that demographic who are listening or will listen and kind of have that mindset when
it comes to leaders.
And and I don't know if it's cynicism.
I don't know if it's just like, well, I've been hurt before or what.
But how, how, how do you see that playing into this context in this conversation?
Well, and, and keep in mind now with the rates of divorce where they are, they've already
seen the key stability in their life.
They've already seen that in.
Oh, right, right, right.
And so why would anything else be more stable than my parents' marriage?
And so since my parents' marriage isn't stable, why would I think anything else is going to
ever be stable?
So when you start there, I mean, you're kind of starting at a huge deficit.
Yeah.
And then, and then to move forward from there, you know, having a youth minister fall or
a pastor fall or you see it on the media when some, you know, big name televangelist turns
out to be a total hypocrite or a con artist.
And like those things kind of add together and it becomes very easy, especially when
you've been abused and we flat out abused in the name of Christ by a pastor or a minister
and you've been sexually abused or physically abused or something like that.
Like, yeah.
I mean, how do you come back from that?
How do you trust that?
And the answer is it's going to be super hard at the emotional level.
But, but the truth is, you know, like there was a Wayne Watson song 25 years ago that
wasn't very famous, but that I liked called That's Not Jesus.
And it was one example after another like that.
And then he would say, but that's not Jesus.
He doesn't carry on that way.
That was just some flesh and blood like you and me that has somehow gone astray.
And that's that is a truism.
It is truth that of course we have that.
And of course it's going to be hard.
And of course, by the way, I'm all about people being, if not cynical, at least dubious.
I'm pretty jaded to it myself that I'm OK if people come visit our church and go, yeah,
I'll wait and see.
You know, that's OK.
Do that.
Be able to do that.
I hope you don't have to do it.
You should be able to.
I'm certainly a skeptic.
So I do that myself quite a bit, mostly about me, but about other other things and people
as well.
But so everything from being being able to recognize me like like John Redford a few
weeks ago, talking on stage about, you know, that he kind of yelled at his son on a Wednesday
night and it's hard to get his son's attention.
I get it.
I've been there and I have a kid like that, too.
It's very hard to get his attention.
And so John kind of barked at him to get his attention and it startled some people.
And so John on Sunday morning just stepped up and was like, hey, some of you heard that.
And that was, you know, me being flesh and blood.
That was me, you know, thinking, well, if I yell at a storm, it'll storm less, which
is ridiculous that I can help end the chaos by yelling.
Well, that's probably not going to work out very well.
And he did a brilliant job, almost poetry, in my opinion, of sharing that.
And we try to model that with the leaders in our church.
So that's why I, you know, reference, I have certain clothes that I can wear on Sunday
morning that are my, they're when I'm in a skinny place and there are others when I'm
in a fatter place.
And because my other addiction is sugar.
And so, and so like, so I, I, I describe myself once as the Oprah Winfrey of pastors that
may not translate very well anymore.
But I meant back in the day when she was always losing and gaining, you know, 20 or 30 pounds
between episodes almost.
And you'd be like, what?
And, but then like four episodes later, she's right back to her heavier weight.
Like, Oh yeah, that's, that's kind of, that's kind of me.
Anyway, it's, it's, I think part of it is the recognition that we're all frail and we're
all sexually frail and we're all needy and we all have hang ups when it comes to sex.
And if you don't draw healthy boundaries and if you don't have good accountability, and
then here's the biggest one for me, Colson, I got to tell you that has scared me over
the years is I've had several lead pastors tell me, and I mean, not in a confession way,
but in a instructive way.
Hey, just know you can't be friends with your congregation.
Yeah.
You can't be friends with your staff and you can't be friends with your leadership.
And I'm like, well, I don't want to do this.
Right?
Like it was the point.
And why, why, why do my whole thing, what is the whole, what's the, what's the reasoning
behind that?
Well, it's, I think I can give you, they say because it's been so much worse when things
go badly.
It's so much worse when people stab you in the back.
It's so much worse when you have to fire somebody.
It's so much worse.
And what struck me even as they were saying it at the time, and I had to listen to them
because they had more experience than I did and really listen and have to dig in and think
about what I believed and then talk to others as well.
And what I realized they mean was it's so much harder on them.
It's so much harder on your, on you when you have to fire a staff member who is a friend.
The truth is though, it may be easier on the staff member because you can love them
through it as a friend, even though you're the one who has to make a call to fire them.
Right.
It's that much harder when I leave, if God calls me to another church or calls me to
another job or another career, it's that much more painful for me if I'm leaving a bunch
of friends.
Well, yeah, but I mean, I just can't see another way to do it that can be even vaguely healthy.
Yeah.
So I try to have close friendships with people on staff and with people in the church and
with leadership and with others.
And I mean, there may be certain things that getting together a group of pastors that we
can talk about that would not be easy to talk about in other places.
That's true.
I think that's true of any career path, especially one that has responsibilities.
But man, I just, I think that's why they fall is because they don't have a Jonathan.
Yeah.
And, you know, Jonathan is so sad.
Jonathan was dead before David falls with Bathsheba and Uriah and that whole nightmare
where he breaks essentially all 10 commandments in a period of six months.
And I've always said, how sad that at that stage in his life, there was no one in David's
life who could come to him and say, why are you still in the palace?
And it says very clearly in that passage.
It was, you know, spring when Kings go to war and David was in his palace.
It's a clear editorial on the fact that David's not supposed to be in his palace and his men
are out fighting and he's not with them.
And it's not good.
But there's no one in David's life who could come and say, hey, what are you doing here?
Your men are in war and you're here.
Get up off your rear end, get off that throne and go to war with your men.
Well, you're not, you shouldn't be here.
And when I asked my wife one time, hey, so if I started really messing up, if I really
started kind of going off the deep end in some way, are there people in my life who
you could kind of call in to confront me?
That you could send into the throne room, so to speak and say, hey, what are you doing?
And she kind of chuckled.
She was like, oh, there's a huge line of people who would love nothing more than to get to
call you out in that moment.
Call you out in that moment.
You're like, okay, great, great.
That's all I needed to hear.
Yeah, exactly.
That's all I needed to know.
Exactly.
Yeah.
Well, and so kind of going back to what we had been talking about specifically with leaders
that had been outstanding, falling, or even that it comes out after they've passed away,
I think a lot of times, and I'm even, and I can get discouraged by this too, and I'm
sure other people do, of like, oh, well, does this just discredit everything they were
talking about?
Yeah.
You know, because I know that there, I mean, there is even another podcast that I was listening
to recently of like talking about building up the, or talking about like restoring the
credibility of the church and how those things can kind of diminish the credibility in a
way in the public eye.
And so what, I don't know, if somebody's, that if that's somebody's question, their
deconstruction of like, look, I was, I really held this person in high regard.
I mean, and I know you, we have said like, okay, you know, we need to deconstruct our
faith in humanity.
What do you say to people who are like, can I still believe this?
Even though this person who I really thought was living the right way, wasn't like, should
I now stop listening to their old sermons and things that I really was comforted and
encouraged by?
Yeah.
That's a, so one, should you stop listening to their old sermons or should you, you know,
throw away all your notebooks or that kind of stuff?
I don't think that's necessary, though it's certainly understandable.
Right.
It's certainly understandable why you would go like, I just don't feel like I can trust
them.
Well, apparently you can't.
Right.
You can't trust them.
And it's a great, you know, it's one of those moments I think that most of us face at some
point when we do have to decide, is my faith in my parents or is it in God?
Is my faith in my youth minister or is it in God?
Now I'm not, I'm not minimizing those people.
I mean, they need to answer for that.
When they bring things down, when they do that, when they cause one of these little
ones to stumble, I mean, Jesus is pretty clear about that.
That's not okay.
You need to be careful not to ever do that.
And yet people do.
So the answer would be the truth has to still be the truth no matter who says it.
That if someone who is absolutely, you know, an anti-religion, atheistic, you know, ungod,
whatever, just pick the furthest from the truth.
But if they say something that's true, it's still true.
Right.
And a pastor who is, you know, a wolf in sheep's clothing, if what they said is true, it's
still true.
Now, you certainly now have to go back and reevaluate is what they said true at a new
level.
Was it true or were they using that to manipulate and lie like a cult leader or converse?
And so you can evaluate it for its truth.
I've actually moved people who have been from a therapy perspective, needed to work through
this.
We'll go back and listen to old sermons from people like that and we'll evaluate them.
Is this true or is it not?
Is this true or is it not?
But it's weird for them because a lot of times they've never put themselves in the
position to evaluate these people.
Yeah.
So it's just like, well, like thinking critically, thinking on their own kind of a thing.
Yeah.
Okay.
Yeah.
What does the Bible actually say?
So to go back and evaluate, okay, is this right?
What they said right is the example they used as a teach what it needs to teach.
And I'm amazed at how often people just very uncritically listen to a pastor or a teacher
and then just swallow that.
And I hope for their sake it's true versus what happened in the church of Berea in the
book of Acts.
That when Paul came and taught to them, they then went back to the scriptures and tested
what he said against the scriptures before they decided to believe what he said.
And I think that's appropriate.
I think that's totally, that's a good thing to do is that you want a leader, a pastor,
a teacher who is humble and who is learning and who doesn't think they have all the answers
and who doesn't have it all together and is able to acknowledge that, who is able to have
friends in the church, in his congregation and among his leaders who is willing to do
those things.
And I mean, I'm not saying those things because they're things about me.
I try to make those things true about me because I think they are right.
They're true.
And but I totally understand it.
And we would love to, I mean, gosh, we'd be happy for anybody who says, I don't know what
to do.
This person who I had placed my trust in has abandoned me, has been unfaithful to me.
There's a lot of ways that it feels like spiritual adultery when a pastor falls that, you know,
they've been with that pastor sometimes five years, 10 years, 20 years, 30 years, and then
they fall.
Well, that feels a little bit like if your spouse cheated on you.
Like I've got to go back and reevaluate everything.
Looking back is, well, that wasn't true.
Then what about this?
Was this true?
Was this true?
Was this true?
And it can be so disconcerting and understandably so.
And that's actually one of the things I enjoy doing as a counselor and as a pastor is talking
through that with people.
Just talking through, hey, you've been let down and you're going to be let down again.
And if you came to church in South spring, you're going to be let down again.
I promise we will let you down.
All of us will.
And you'll let me down.
So it's fair.
I mean, you'll let me down.
I'll let you down.
That's how this works.
But that doesn't mean we don't love each other.
And because foundationally, I'm not dependent upon you and you aren't dependent upon me
for our faith.
And so, yeah, absolutely.
It should cause us to go back and reevaluate them.
Of course, it should cause us to go back and rethink what they taught us.
And that can be a painful process for sure.
And we're not obligated to continue to trust them or listen to them.
We do have to figure out a process for forgiving them, which doesn't mean they become our pastor
again.
Doesn't mean we let them babysit our children.
It doesn't mean we loan them money.
It doesn't mean any of that kind of stuff.
It just means that at some point we come to the place of realizing Christ has paid
all our debts and we can afford to forgive other people their debts, no matter how awful
they are.
And that's a hard process.
And we don't have time on this podcast to talk about that.
But it can be a challenging, hard covenant to decide to forgive somebody.
And there'll be days when you're good at it and days when you're bad at it.
It's like with any other covenant.
But yeah, that is something Christ calls us to.
And Christ is the one we listen to, not people when there's disagreement.
So it's understandable why that would be so hard.
And I will tell you, it's infuriating.
As a pastor, it is infuriating when we see a pastor fall in pride or arrogance or lust,
whatever fleshly thing they fall into, especially when they've lied about it, they've pretended
like they had it all together.
That stuff is just infuriating me as a pastor because it does put a dark mark against the
gospel.
Yeah.
Man.
Experientially, not truthfully, but experientially.
Yeah, yeah, yeah.
Yeah, man.
Anyway, well, so this is something we're seeing and we would love for anybody who needs to
reach out and say, that's me.
You're talking about me.
My pastor, the person I admired, my ministry leader turned out to be a horrible person.
And if it's just that you got crossways with them, well, you're both horrible people.
And so that's going to happen sometimes between humans.
Humans are going to get crossways with each other because we're horrible.
But sometimes it truly is a one directional.
Someone just fell and failed.
And how do we restore them appropriately?
How do we confront them appropriately?
Those are all conversations I've had with many people over the years and know I'll have
more.
And it's sad, but it's what we would predict as Christians.
Yeah.
Yeah.
Any faith you put in humans is eventually going to get let down to one degree or another.
Oh, yeah.
Well, if you're listening right now, and this is something that you have walked through
and the Lord has used to, you know, to grow something in you or you have a story to share,
we'd love to hear that.
And so please feel free to reach out to me at clechner at southspring.org.
We can kind of continue that conversation.
Any closing thoughts, Chris?
Thank you so much for taking a call and sharing.
Even though you're out in the wilderness, there is a little bit of wind, but for the
most part, you are you're you're easy to hear.
And I think we'll be able to get some some really good meat out of the conversation,
despite the elements.
Good, good.
Well, maybe my my lack of sleep may be less clear, but being out in the wilderness, maybe
that makes my thoughts clear.
So hopefully there'll be something valuable in that conversation.
And I would tell somebody exactly what we kind of end the podcast with.
Don't give up.
Keep struggling.
Keep trying.
Keep asking those hard questions and keep digging in.
And when humans let us down, we grieve, we mourn, we struggle.
We can be persecuted, but we're not abandoned, struck down, but not destroyed.
And that's hopefully the perspective we can take, even when those nearest to us fall.
And I hate to think about how that would have been affected, like what are these people's
kids and spouses and what do they deal with?
But but it's real for us as well.
So for us to allow ourselves to grieve and struggle, but remind ourselves where our help
comes from.
And it's not primarily it's not fundamentally from other humans.
Yeah, as important as we are.
There you go.
Yeah, great word.
Well, thanks, Chris.
And thank you for listening.
And we'll see you in the next episode.
Thank you for joining us for this episode of Reconstructed Faith.
If you enjoyed what you heard or were challenged, please leave us a review.
We'll help other people find us.
If you have questions or a topic you'd like to hear discussed, shoot me an email at info
at southspring.org.
Reconstructed Faith is a resource of South Spring Baptist Church.
Remember, don't give up.
Trust God.
